title: What will be the closing yield for the 30-year U.S. Treasury on 22 September 2020?
preds: Updating with current values of today.
Current price and recent trading behaviour around the close
Last update based on current trading data.
Final day of moves, updating given BBG analysts.
One final day of moves left, given that we dipped below 1.4 today I think that the crowd is probably underweight that bucket.
1 more day of trading left, 30Y closed at 1.418 and I think it's more likely than not to settle in the 3rd bucket.
Updated given recent movement; going over other people's numbers, I feel like I may be understating vol, but think I did my calculations correctly
Reversing again. The drop may have been temporary, it's been pretty stable.

1.406% again...
I think I'll stick to this now, as markets seem to calm down a bit, at least that's what the sinking VIX (for the moment) suggests.

Going the other way again...
So many thrillers at once is not good for my nerves.
Reversing back after the change over the weekend.
Moving probabilities as time is almost up and barring no major news, we should settle into 3rd bucket.

The 30-year Treasury yield closed at 1.45 on Friday, Sept. 18th. There are only two trading days left. 
On Monday, there will be a new release. For a treasury yield to move down 5 bps, there needs to be a significant volatility event. Usually, the new release on Monday will steepen the yield a little bit because of the sudden new supply of bonds. Given that the inflation expectation should not have a significant change in the upcoming week. It is very likely that the yield price will stay within the 1.4 - 1.6 basket for a while.  If I were wrong, the mistake could be from a huge volatility event that drags down the curve happening on Monday/Tuesday. This event could be a student huge demand for bonds (for example, when investors think the economy is doomed and want safer environment), a monetary policy action to boost inflation, etc.
Updating given current yield is 1.455% on Friday AMC and there is little time remaining with no significant catalysts.
Updating given current yield 1.455 % at friday close and time remaining.
Updating given current yield and time remaining.
Moving higher as time is running out.
Yield currently trading 1.45, and will update accordingly. With only 2 more days we'd need to see a 3.5% drop in yields in order to reach the lower bucket.
Going back to favoring 1.4 to 1.6, looks like it's holding steady.

Thanks @ashalom for the update regarding 30y yields that increase on the Fed announcement. During yesterday meeting, FOMC laid out a more ambitious economic goal: they prolonged the economic support and said they expected to keep interest rates near zero for at least the next three years. [2] [3] More precise notes [1] from the meeting  “aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 per cent for some time so that inflation averages 2 per cent over time and longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 per cent”.   “maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy until these outcomes are achieved”  ->there is no plan of tighten policy + uncertainty of the forecast decreases . Consequently, U.S futures declining and Treasuries gaining. The dollar edged up after Jerome Powell highlighted uncertainty about the future.  So I update my prediction slightly to the right.  [1] https://www.ft.com/content/827302da-4257-4bbc-a0fa-9bc98f65d661
[2] https://consent.yahoo.com/v2/collectConsent?sessionId=3_cc-session_d94d7e5a-f6dd-4e81-90a7-89ac110aa3a0
[3] https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-54183079

As @ashalom pointed out, the FOMC meeting came as a no surprise, thus yields remained at the levels they were before (slight push upwards). This makes the 1.4-1.6% node more likely as we do not expect any other catalyst in the period.

Cutting out tails a bit to reflect time decay. It is likely that yields finish below 1.4%, but I'm slightly increasing my >1.4% bucket due to there being slightly less uncertainty following the FOMC today.
Due to Powell's latest speech and little movement on stimulus bill.

Powell's speech indicates letting inflation run hot over 2% -> more inflation expectations. 30y yields rallied after the speech and are around 1.45% now. Post mortem: Major shock to system leading flight to bonds, new language from Fed, reversion based on Vasicek model.

Yields haven't really been above 1.4% in the past 2 weeks, and during FOMC meeting today they affirmed plans to not worry about inflation in short term, and commit to an averaged inflation policy. This implies that short-term interest rates are likely to remain low, while having a long-term target for averaged inflation would imply longer-end rates will be higher, thus pushing yields for 30y bonds upwards. Because of this, I think it's more likely that curve steepens than flattens, which would imply 30y bonds having yields above 1.4%.
+13 on 1.4 to 1.6 due to time remaining.

As time decays I decrease my lowest bucket from 2 to 1,  - today main event FOMC 2pm statement and 2:30pm news conference; focus is on potential for inflation-outcome-based guidance and changes to size or distribution of Fed’s Treasury purchases, which most strategists consider unlikely for this month  - change since my last update: current value is 1.408 %, with small decrease over the last 5 last days so regarding the other buckets i just slightly update my distribution to the left
Yields trading closer to the 1.4 mark after a small drop.
Adjusting for time passing and being above 1.4%
Updated using the Bloomberg forecasts for the 30-year yield. As we approach the settlement date, probability will continue to be concentrated in the middle two buckets.
Updating as 30 year yield continues to find support at 1.4% level. Moving lowest bucket to zero as vol has become muted.
Updated initial conditions in MC simulation

I generated a random walk with steps drawn from the distribution of changes in treasury yields over the last month. I think this is a good approach because policy has remained relatively consistent over this period and is expected to remain consistent, implying that the past distribution of changes is largely reflective of the distribution in the near-term future.
Tighten distribution based on time passing.
Using rogers skew of the normal distribution implied by the 30 day vol, taken as one standard deviation.
Used my team's forecasts as my starting point. Then increased weight of lowest bucket to account for skewness of markets.

Refitted Vasicek model and took into account team prediction. Model suggests EV of 1.37% but team seems to be more in the 1.4 - 1.6% bucket so I split the diff between the 1.2 - 1.4% and 1.4 - 1.6% buckets.
Similar to my previous forecasts. Monte carlo simulation using market data to derive underlying price distribution. No adjustments made to the curve here.

Refitted model using Vasicek this time with 2 month lookback and backed out probabilities. Low vol environment for rates as well makes it unlikely to move in extremes. Skewed down 2nd bucket / skewed up 3rd bucket after taking into account my team's info.
Agree with @vkasat's approach, the movements in rates don't appear to be directional but rather around a mean. Not much news on the rates front since last week at Jackson Hole
Looks like it's hovering around 1.4. I don't know a lot about treasuries but I'll lean slightly on the lower side and guess that it'll dip back down on the basis that the economy is still weak.

Yields fell slightly after stocks fell over the last few trading days, currently at 1.418. An event to note is the release of August 2020 US CPI data on Friday, which would push rates up if higher inflation is expected.
Used swaption implied vol to get a variance for a normal distribution, then adjust slightly for a more realistic distribution since normal may not be appropriate.
Tightening a bit around center of distribution after further drop in SPX leading yields to increase very slightly

Updating forecast given current market data, and the fact that market seems to be expecting higher rates over long term due to Fed's new average inflation policy, leading to higher yields than initially anticipated.
Updating based on latest drop today and no sign of reversal in current economic downturn.

30Y yields have been low but somewhat volatile over the past several months. However, very little of this volatility was directional; that is, yields were not tending in a direction, but rather volatile about some center. Because of this, I chose to model potential yield paths over the next two weeks using a lognormal distribution of 'returns' (increases/decreases in yield).

In the short term a couple of factors will drive 30 year yields, 1) increased supply 2) news of China slowly offloading treasury holdings 3) the Fed's increased tolerance for inflation to run above 2%. I'm biased towards bear steepening of the curve right now.
Worked with @ashishk96 on this. Used swaption implied norm vol for 1Mx30Y. Skew at this point was quite flat so just used norm vol (~80bps when checked) of rates.

Taking inspiration from my colleagues @dzhou3  and @cls, I downloaded the historical yeild data, splicing it from April 1st to present, and performed a monte carlo simulation using both the CIR and Vasicek models. One thing that was very apparant, was that the rate of mean reversion drastically altered results. For example, using a high rate of mean reversion,we almost guarantee that the yield will remain around 1.37 - the mean during the time period in my question. Using a mean reversion rate of 0, yield a wide range of results. Using a variety of mean reversion parameters, the distribution for outcomes is as follows: Less than 1.2%: ~10%
Bw 1.2 and 1.4: ~55%
Bw 1.4 and 1.6: ~35%
Bw 1.6 and 1.8: ~1% Since I have no prior on the rate of mean reversion for US Treasury yields, I use my quantitative results combined with some qualitative insight to arrive at my final distribution. Specifically, last week at Jackson Hole, Powell strongly indicated that he intends to keep interest rates low in the near term as the Fed will target average inflation. Barring any market shock type event, I am more inclined to place heavier weigh on rates staying at there current level, between the 1.4 and 1.6 bucket.

The 30-year treasury yield closed at 1.46 on Friday (although this is after quite a big move upwards). That leaves 11 trading days until close on 9/22. In order to see how treasury yields are changing post COVID, I then decided to look at the distribution of daily pct_change since April 1. This looked roughly normally distributed with a (mean, std) of (0.00133, 0.03516). With this, we can find the 11-day pct_change distribution will be distributed as N(0.0146, 0.1166). Finally with this we can calculate the buckets above giving the distribution above.  Update: Instead of using Friday's close I will use a yield more in line with an average over the past few days, this is seeing from other forecasts mentioning that yields have hovered in the 1.2-1.5 range over the past couple of months. It seems I'm likely underestimating the mean-reversion element interest rates. Will have to look more into this upon market open on Tuesday.

Baseline: The 30 year Treasury rate has been between 1.2% and 1.6% since May (except a during a selloff in the first week of June). Unfortunately, it is quite challenging to use any typical interest rate factor model (e.g. Vasicek, Hull-White, CIR, Black-Karasinski) as, due to the pandemic, interest rates have turned very volatile and prone to the underlying assumptions. Therefore, we rather look at past sentiments in different market times and the implied Treasury yield to understand how investors price this Treasury in different situations. Setting the 1.4% as threshold, we see that markets are comfortably below 1.4% on some negative news and get above 1.4% on positive news. Since the Jackson Hole meeting, the Fed has given quite a lot of clarity into the future interest rate environment and market has been pricing this in by generally increasing the yield. Adjustments:
Fed meeting:
There will be another Fed meeting on September 16, however unless there is a major catalyst, there should be no major surprise from the Fed and they will reiterate their policy. Conclusion: there is no convincing argument for either bucket (1.2-1.4 and 1.4-1.6) yet, therefore we would generally give equal probability to both. However, yields have increased in general lately, thus we attribute slightly more probability to the later bucket.
Fixed some code errors in simulation

Reran Monte Carlo simulation with new data, and using 3 months of historical data rather than 1 year. Tried fitting a normal distribution to returns due to lack of data when changing the lookback period to 3 months. I changed the lookback period due to the change in vol regime that occurred during Covid that I previously did not consider. Despite heightened volatility at the end of last week, I tightened my distribution from the simulation output even further than last time because we are closer to settlement of this question, and because Powell indicated again that we will very likely continue to have low rates for the medium term, effectively establishing a soft upper bound.

Base rate: I used the Cox–Ingersoll–Ross model [1] to describe the evolution of interest rates. It is a type of one factor model as it describes interest rate movements as driven by only one source of market risk modelled by a Wiener process. The calibration of parameters is complex given and needs the use of AR process [2]. To simplify I consider the speed of mean reverting to be 0. For the mean and volatility parameters I used year to date data. I then simulate the path of interest from Friday close close (1.473) to 22 September 10000 times, giving to following results: 
2% Less than 1.200%
30% Between 1.200% and 1.400%, inclusive
54% More than 1.400% but less than 1.600%
14% Between 1.600% and 1.800%, inclusive
0% More than 1.800% Adjustment:
Historical data includes March-April unprecedented times in term of Federal reserve’s decision + very high level of beginning of the y and might not be a fair representation of the next month data. That’s why I adjust quite a lot those results considering: 
-	no major fed reserve announcements planned by analysts -> I see very few probabilities for the rate to go above 1.6 
-	my simulations takes as initial value the 1.473 rate of Friday greatly boosted after unemployment rate drops (news now absorbed by the market)  
-> therefore I split the weight of the 4th bucket into the 2nd one for ¾ and the 3rd one  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cox%E2%80%93Ingersoll%E2%80%93Ross_model
[2] https://quant.stackexchange.com/questions/17156/how-can-i-estimate-the-ornstein-uhlenbeck-paramters-of-some-mean-reverting-data

I assume a simpler version of the Vaisek model (without mean reversion). Calibrating to data from May 1st till September 9th, we get a mean of 1.385% and a std of 0.104%. As such, by quick and dirty normal cdf calculations, we have 4% chance of less than 1.2%, 52% chance of between 1.2% - 1.4%, 42% chance of 1.4% - 1.6%, 2% chance of 1.6% - 1.8% and 0% chance of more than 1.8%. On the macro front, we have a Fed meeting on September 15th - 16th. However, given Powell's remarks last week at Jackson Hole, it seems like the markets have already reacted to his news to keep rates low. As @ashalom points out, rates are effectively at a zero lower bound when you account for inflation. Powell has also been quite explicit about his views on keeping rates low for the next 2 years, which has kept the front end of the yield curve quite depressed and reasonably lowering volatility across the yield curve. As such, I lower the probability for the MC simulation at the tails and move more towards the center.

Bootstrap Monte Carlo using past year's interest rate returns looking forward 13 days as a baseline, yielding 17, 36, 29, 12, 6. Recent low interest rate volatility, and Fed has indicated that they will keep rates low for an extended period of time, so I tightened the distribution and skewed downwards a bit.

Yields have been between 1.35 - 1.51 range since mid August. Yields today dropped to 1.32 (at the lowest point) amid market turmoil. Next FOMC meeting is 9/16, rates already close to ZLB, thus would be surprising to see yields drop below 1.2 (but not impossible). Employment/economic data will likely be unimpressive, and thus wouldn't be surprising for yields to decrease, therefore skewed the distribution downwards.
30 yr shouldn't be lower than 1.2% due to new inflation target. There's a big dip in rates today due to spy downward move.
